ICYMI: On Friday, I introduced H.R. 539, the USPSTF Transparency and Accountability Act which would fundamentally reform the United States Preventative Services Task Force by requiring the following:  · Enhances transparency by allowing Congressional oversight of USPSTF recommendations  ·  Provides public input regarding the development of USPSTF recommendations  ·  Allows needed consultation with those who treat the specific disease in question   This bill is an important step to reform this flawed system and replace it with provisions that allow patients and doctors to individually choose what is right for their health plan.

The Protecting Sensitive Locations Act (H.R. 1815) filed by House Democrats is just another example of their desire to turn America into a sanctuary country.  This bill would prevent ICE agents from arresting or even interviewing illegal aliens at “sensitive” locations, such as courthouses, probation offices, social service centers, congressional offices and many other areas.  It is the job of Congress to create laws, not encourage disregard for them.  If we are going to ask the “thin blue line” to keep Americans safe, we shouldn’t make them do it with one hand tied behind their back.  Sanctuary policies endanger Americans and must be stopped.

This week marked National Police Week. National Police Week began in 1962 as a way to honor those law enforcement officers who made the ultimate sacrifice. Today and every day, we remember those whose didn’t come home and their families who are left with a void.  We also recognize those who serve and protect our communities day in and day out. I spoke on the House floor this week to honor Sergeant Paul Arnold of the Franklin Police Department. Sergeant Arnold is a 26-year Franklin Police veteran, and in July of last year, for the third time, he was diagnosed with cancer.

Fred Thompson was a neighbor, a friend, and a trusted political voice. Dedicated to first principles and conservative values from the start of his career in Sen. Howard Baker’s office, Fred Thompson made a lasting impression on the state of Tennessee. He loved our state and her people.   In March we passed a bill I sponsored in the House to name the new federal courthouse in Nashville in his honor. I am so pleased yesterday the Senate passed the bill. It is now awaiting the President's signature.   Passing this legislation is an appropriate way to show our respect for Senator Thompson's commitment to the people of Tennessee.

As many enjoy the long weekend with barbecues and festivities, we should take time to remember those sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, fathers, and mothers who have given their lives in the defense of ours. Click below for my message to you this Memorial Day.

My constituent, Martha Bolton, wrote for the legendary Bob Hope for 30 years. She knew him, his sense of humor, his timing, his love of our military first hand, up close and personal. Her Memorial Day post is so touching, I wanted to share with you.  Enjoy the read.  THANKS FOR THE MEMORIES AND THE SACRIFICE  It seems appropriate that Memorial Day would also be the birthday of Bob Hope, a man who gave so much of himself to our military that he was made an honorary veteran by an Act of Congress in 1997. After being presented with the honor by then President Bill Clinton, Bob said, “I’ve been given many awards in my lifetime, but to be numbered among the men and women I admire most is the greatest honor I have ever received.”  The troops meant a lot to Bob Hope. In 1941, after walking on stage at March Field, he knew he had found his audience. Bob Hope entertained 11 presidents in his life time, holds the record for the longest running consecutive contract with a television network (NBC), holds the record for having hosted the Oscars more than any other entertainer, but the military was the audience he held closest to his heart.  Thousands of letters received from GIs tell the story of his deep commitment to them, and his gratitude for their sacrifice. Countless mothers others wrote to thank him for personally calling to say that he had seen their son or daughter on the battlefield and that they sent their love. For some of these moms, it was the last message they received.  Bob Hope knew the importance of bringing laughter to these war-weary men and women, and he was determined to bring it to them. A letter from one soldier clearly shows his determination in that endeavor. The soldier wrote to thank Bob for what he had done for him and his company. He said they had walked to the staging area, but thousands of soldiers were already there and they couldn’t get close enough to see the show. So they started walking back to their camp. Bob heard about their plight and after the show he rounded up some of his troupe, piled them all into a jeep, and went out to find them along the road. Then, they parked and put on a private show just for them. That was Bob Hope.  Bob’s last military tour was in 1990. That's almost fifty years of dedicated service to our troops.  So on this Memorial Day, as we eat our barbecue and spend time with our families, let’s remember the men and women who gave the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom. And let’s also say a prayer for those who continue to serve and protect our country. Bob Hope has passed on, but there is no doubt in my mind that if we were lucky enough to still have him here with us, that's exactly how he would be spending today.  Martha Bolton Former writer for Bob Hope

History Today: Though he was two days off in his prediction, John Adams declared July 2nd, 1776 as the birthday of America. His prediction came as the result of Richard Henry Lee's motion for independence being approved by the Congress on July 2, 1776. This motion officially separated the 13 colonies from Great Britain. On July 4th, 1776, Adams would join his colleagues in signing the Declaration of Independence – the document that articulated the reasons why the colonies separated from the British Empire. Even though he missed the mark by two days, Adams did outline how Americans would celebrate their Independence Day for years to come.  Read more below.   http://bit.ly/2sNX6UL

When we passed the AHCA in the House, we said it was the first step in a three-step approach to making health care more accessible and affordable for Americans. Despite what you may be hearing in the news, the House is still plugging away, working on the third step measures.   Today we take aim at one of the biggest health care cost drivers: medical liability reform.   On the floor today is the Protecting Access to Care Act, a bill designed to address frivolous and costly medical malpractice suits brought by out-of-control trial lawyers. By removing the endless litigation threats facing many doctors, they are better suited to practice medicine that is centered on the patient, not centered on protecting themselves against a lawsuit. The bill also codifies protections to ensure that patients still have access to justice and the ability to recover damages in the event of malpractice.    In addition to lowering health care costs for Americans, the CBO says other measures in the bill will save the taxpayer $50 billion over ten years. This bill is a good start towards attacking the true drivers of today’s steep health care costs. We have more work to do, and we are determined to get it done.

This week, Congress is addressing the lack of immigration enforcement and the spread of dangerous sanctuary policies that have failed the American people and harmed too many lives.   Many times I have said that these sanctuary cities have turned every state into a border state, and every town into a border town. We owe it to the families of those who lost loved ones to take action to prevent these horrible crimes. They have waited far too long.

For years, the lack of immigration enforcement and the spread of dangerous sanctuary policies have failed the American people and cost too many lives, like Kate Steinle, Sarah Root, Grant Ronnebeck.   Read more about the bills we are considering designed to crack down on dangerous sanctuary policies and enhance penalties for deported felons who return to the U.S.

This week’s inappropriate and pointless tweets from the President are a stark example of just what has gone wrong in our political discourse today. Robust yet civil debate over policy disagreements have taken a back seat to thin-skin and knee-jerk reactions to hyper-partisan comments and, unfortunately, unfounded character attacks.   On the day Rep. Steve Scalise and others were shot, seemingly for nothing other than being Republican, not only were we reminded of the consequences of a collapse in civil discourse, but many, including me, renewed our commitment to unity and called for a return to the respectful and civil disagreements that have shaped debate and the political landscape since the birth of our great nation. Our nation and the cause of freedom have been well served by robust and spirited debate.  In this era of 24/7 worldwide news, the President of the United States represents each and every one of us on the world stage. Globally, the President is America, and in this day and age, actions are seen by more and more people and scrutinized more and more intensely around the world. We are right to expect a higher level of civility, graciousness, and diplomacy from our President. We expect the individual who holds the office and the title to rise above the hubris and noise of the day.  While the President is human, and fallible like the rest of us, this current trend needs to stop. This week’s tweets were a step way too far, regardless of what personal exchanges or insults had been hurled. From health care to immigration to trade to infrastructure to terrorism, there are far too many pressing issues facing this country for petty squabbles to be on the President’s radar. I respectfully request, Mr. President, that you turn your focus to the issues we are working on in Congress – the positive solutions we are trying to get to your desk to make America great again. You are delivering on your promises, as are we. Let’s talk more about those and less about one another. The American people would be grateful.  No matter who you are – President of the United States, a cable news anchor, plumber, lawyer, welder, doctor – bombast and ratings should not rank higher than our shared desire to live freely in this country alongside our fellow Americans. We are blessed to live in a country where we are free to express our opinions, no matter how inflammatory or hyperbolic. As a legislator, I work daily to protect those freedoms. But we ought also to remember that we are all a part of a greater humanity, and that civility in our interactions – both personal and digital – is not only proper, but fundamental to a respectful and prosperous society.

I hope everyone had a wonderful weekend as we spend time with friends, family, and neighbors to celebrate the birth of our free and independent nation. We are truly blessed to live in this great country, and I urge you to take a moment to reflect on those who risked or given their lives in defense of our cherished freedoms.  Have a wonderful and safe Fourth of July!

Today the House passed National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2018, our annual defense funding authorization bill.   We have a profound obligation to provide for the common defense. It is our job to ensure those who selflessly serve have the tools and resources they need to keep Americans safe. For those soldiers and their families at Fort Campbell, this bill is a big win, helping relieve shortfalls in personnel, funding, and resources that have strained operations and morale for some time. I am pleased to see this bill pass and hopeful the Senate will take quick action on it. #FY18NDAA

We need to simplify and streamline the rules and regulations in the permitting process for natural gas pipelines to provide the certainty business and workers desire, the freedom to grow and modernize the nation's natural gas pipeline, and the more affordable energy prices Americans depend upon.  Rep. Bill Flores' HR 2910 promotes timely and efficient reviews and strengthens FERC's lead agency role to bring certainty and transparency to the permitting process.

Click below to read more about a couple of manufacturers in Tennessee’s Seventh District that pride themselves on making quality, home grown American products – Diamond Gusset Jean Co. and the Mason Corporation.

Today the FDA announced the launch of its Pre-Cert for Software Pilot Program, which implements my SOFTWARE Act legislation. With the speed at which today’s technology changes and updates, the FDA’s traditional, heavy-handed regulatory framework simply isn’t feasible for things such as apps, which can provide a significant benefit to consumers and patients so long as they have access to them before its obsolete.   This is a big win for Tennessee's vast health care industry and the jobs it creates.  By employing a light-touch regulatory approach and establishing a thorough pre-certification program, developers will be able to efficiently deliver the latest technology to those who stand to benefit most from it. The FDA program changes the regulatory process for certain medical devices, allowing firms making digital health products such as apps, to get their technology into the hands of patients and consumers so they can reap the benefits of the latest innovations and take an active role in their own health care.

I'm grateful so many of you from Tennessee's 7th District joined me last night for a live telephone town hall. From counties all across our district, we had a good conversation and you asked some great questions about health care, border security, the deficit/spending, ongoing media attacks, and how the House and Senate can work together to solve our country’s problems.  Throughout the call, I asked you to weigh in on a few issues using our polling feature, and you responded:

As a member of House Committee on Energy and Commerce, I have worked to help lower drug costs and bring new treatments and innovative medical devices to patients everywhere. Now, the Senate has acted and passed H.R. 2430, the FDA User Fee Reauthorization Act with a #bipartisan vote of 94-1. This bill has been a large priority for all of us in the House, as it will bring new treatments, innovative medical devices and more affordable medicines to patients.  I am particularly pleased to see the bill contain the Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid measure I sponsored in the House. This is a true win for the millions of Americans struggling with hearing loss and the costs associated with it. Making hearing aids more accessible and affordable is a commonsense measure and I am glad to see bipartisan support in both chambers come together to pass this for the American people.  I look forward to President Trump signing this bill into law.
Great to chat with so many of you and answer your questions at the Maury Alliance Chamber & Rotary "Eggs & Issues" event this morning in Columbia!
Had a great discussion with NFIB Tennessee and Lawrence County leaders on rural broadband, health care, tax reform, and issues important to #TN7 businesses. Thank you for having me.

In some big news for our district and Tennesseans across the state working in or connected to the Health Care Technology industry: the FDA announced they are implementing my SOFTWARE ACT in a new program. This will change the regulations for digital health products—like apps—to let patients take a more active role in their own health care. You will remember that the bill was included with the passage of our bipartisan 21st Century Cures Act and signed into law last December by President Obama.

I spoke with the Rotary Club of Lawrenceburg, TN about what we have been doing in Washington. Many were surprised to learn we have passed over 400 bills in the House this year.   #DidYouKnow  what we have passed in the House? Click the link to learn more: https://www.didyouknow.gop/

At a multi-county gathering of Tennessee Farm Bureau Federation, I was honored to help announce that the Tennessee College of Applied Technology - Hohenwald is receiving a $50,000 Rural Development Grant.
Enjoyed spending time discussing and recapping House work on issues important to #TN7 at the Hohenwald/Lewis County Chamber of Commerce this evening.

This week is National #FarmersMarketWeek — the 18th consecutive year the Department of Agriculture celebrates the critical role local farmers play in the nation’s food system. And I couldn’t be more delighted to put farmers in the 7th district center stage. Click below to read my blog on what our #TN7 farmers markets are doing for you!

I stand with the President, Vice President, and the administration in condemning, in the strongest possible terms, the violence, bigotry, and hatred displayed this weekend in Charlottesville. Racism, white supremacy, and neo-Nazism have no place in civil society. We must learn from history, not repeat it.

Happy Birthday, 101st Airborne Division (Air Assault) Screaming Eagles!  Your birth during World War II and your critical roles on D-Day, in the Battle of the Bulge and Hamburger Hill, your leadership in Iraq, Afghanistan and the Middle East are unparalleled.   You earned this birthday the way the Army earns everything—with grit, perseverance, and dedication. Your service is legendary and your accomplishments advance the cause of freedom.   Congratulations on 75 years of continuous service to the United States of America!

I am truly saddened to hear of the passing of Jo Walker-Meador, a beloved mentor who challenged me to dream big dreams and work hard to make them come true. I will deeply miss her tender words of encouragement and her interest in my family and work. My heart and prayers go out to her family, friends, and loved ones.

I am saddened by the tragic news of the terror attack in Barcelona. Our thoughts and prayers go out to the victims of this senseless attack and the people of Barcelona. This evil has no place in our world and we must do all we can to eradicate terrorism, in all shapes and forms.

Good to see some of our #TN7 constituents and spend some time with our Tennessee Titans this week at one of their practices. With Marcus Mariota at the helm, the squad is looking good as they enter their first preseason game Saturday against the Carolina Panthers. Join me in wishing them the best and getting the first of many wins this year!

On Monday the Moon will pass between the Sun and the Earth, and its shadow will sweep across the country. As we prepare for #Eclipse2017, the Smithsonian has compiled a number of good resources for you at the link below. From the path of the eclipse to eye safety to what to expect, they have it all!

BIG NEWS: The President has signed the FDA Reauthorization Act into law. This bill includes a measure I sponsored in the House, the Over-the Counter Hearing Aid Act, to make hearing aids more affordable and more accessible by allowing certain types of hearing aids to be regulated by the FDA and marketed over-the-counter in your neighborhood drug stores, malls, and shopping centers.   This is a true win for the millions of Americans struggling with hearing loss and the costs associated with it. Making hearing aids more accessible and affordable is a commonsense measure, and I am glad to see this signed into law today!

What fun to join family, fans, friends, and Nolensville's elected officials to send off Chase Goehring to the America's Got Talent finals! Nothing like a hometown crowd to cheer you on to the Live Performance Round.
Today is the day! For the first time in almost 100 years, a total solar eclipse will cross the entire United States. What are you doing for #Eclipse2017? Let me know in the comments.

President Trump’s remarks tonight outlined a strategy that has been sorely missing in our fight against terrorism around the world. Setting conditions-based rather than time-based goals, the President has changed the rules of engagement to ensure that American leadership will result in an honorable and enduring outcome. I applaud the President’s commitment to listening to his military commanders, eradicating terror and ensuring the safety of the American people while understanding American might alone will not achieve these goals. The President laid out a measured and balanced approach that employs the economic, diplomatic, and military resources needed to get the job done once and for all.

Kicked off today’s listening tour with Christianson Patterson Courtney & Associates realtors from Williamson and Davidson Counties to discuss tax relief and answer questions about other issues important to them. From there we visited the Nashville Electric Service, where the team provided a Cyber Security Review. Maintaining safe, reliable, efficient power is critical to the mission of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

You never know what's behind the front door of a local company. It was great to visit employees and tour The Doug Jeffords Company--a family-owned, custom spice and seasoning blend operation, serving the food industry in the Southeastern U.S.
Good to meet the employees of Best Buy in Brentwood this afternoon to get an overview of how retail is changing with new technology.
Always fun to be in the kitchen, punch a little dough, spread a little sauce with the staff of Jet's Pizza. Small business in action.
HealthSouth--soon to be Encompass Health--demonstrates their patient motto: Get them home--stronger, safer, sooner. Great to have a national leader in the post-acute care sector right in #TN7 !

Had a great evening with the proud members of American Legion Post 156! The dinner was good, the discussion was better, and the friendship, patriotism, and camaraderie shown by these veterans was best. Thank you for having me tonight!
Good to chat about rural broadband with Ken Gentry and his staff Fast Forward Unlimited Broadband, a small provider in Humphreys County.

Humbled and honored to meet Pilot Matthew Blackwell and Air Evac Life Team in Waverly. In addition to several deployments to Afghanistan, Matthew has flown over 400 patients and the trauma teams to care facilities. God bless him and the entire team as they continue to help the people of Humphreys County!

Honored to take part in the groundbreaking ceremony for the LG Electronics USA appliance manufacturing facility in Clarksville. The 600+ jobs it will bring and the potential for future expansion are very welcome in #TN7. We are grateful for President Trump's and the Administration's emphasis on putting Americans first and reviving manufacturing jobs here in America. Welcome to #TN7, LG Electronics!

It was a great privilege to provide a "View From Congress" to the Healthcare Information & Management Systems Society (HIMSS) attendees in Nashville today. Health IT plays a large role in Tennessee, and with technology advancing at unprecedented rates, it will continue to impact #TN7 more and more. Thank you @HIMSS for the chance to speak with such a great group of dedicated professionals on such an important topic!

It was my pleasure and honor to present the The Congressional Award Bronze Medal to Franklin High School senior Marshall Morrison for voluntary public service, personal development, physical fitness and expedition/exploration. Marshall #Earnedit by unloading packages and serving customers with Cooper's Troopers, developing his Spanish skills outside his school lessons, devising a year-round conditioning plan for the varsity basketball team, and working with the Great Smoky Mountains National Park rangers to plan a rigorous and scenic hike on the Appalachian Trail. This award requires a minimum of 200 hours and seven months of initiative and achievement, and is the U.S. Congress' highest honor bestowed upon our youth. Congratulations, Marshall!
"Few will notice this accomplishment by Congress, but it’s a classic example of a market improvement that will expand choice and benefit public health."

With Clarksville playing home to so many of our Fort Campbell soldiers and veterans, it was a pleasure to meet with people who are working to make sure our nation’s bravest have access to skills education to gain employment beyond their service and put an end to veteran unemployment in our area. Hiller Plumbing, Heating, Cooling & Electrical, in conjunction with U.S. Army Fort Campbell Career Skills Program, have worked to provide that education and put our men and women in uniform back into the workforce. Leadership is not as it appears, but as it performs. We are thankful for your leadership on behalf of our veterans and their families.

Incredible to see what CDL drivers go through as they learn to drive the tractor trailers that transport so many goods across the country. At Miller-Motte Technical College, prospective drivers take an intensive class to learn this invaluable skill. When they are done, they are ready to hit the job market with an in-demand skill! Thank you for allowing me to visit and see this top-notch education in action!

Great turnout at the Kiwanis Club of Clarksville, TN today. I enjoyed taking your questions and hearing from you about the issues we are facing in Congress and here at home. Thank you so much for the hospitality and the chance to be with you!

Our thoughts and prayers are with those in Texas and Louisiana as they endure this awful disaster. Tennesseans stand ready to help in any way we can and many are already on the ground lending assistance.

As Harvey passes through Texas and Louisiana, Tennessee is expected to get a lot of rain as the storm continues through the states. While it is not expected to be severe, there may be some flash flooding in areas and the situation may change as the storm progresses. Please be safe if the storms are bad and avoid getting out in the storm if you can.  Read more on what to expect at the links below:  http://www.newschannel5.com/news/rain-from-harvey-expected-for-to-hit-tn-ky  https://weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/tropical-storm-harvey-forecast-texas-louisiana-arkansas  http://wkrn.com/2017/08/29/remnants-of-harvey-to-impact-middle-tennessee/  http://whnt.com/2017/08/29/harvey-heads-inland-wednesday-bringing-rain-and-a-threat-of-strong-storms/  http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/08/28/hurricane-harvey-labor-day-weather-forecast-nashville-tn-middle/607564001/

President Trump continues to prioritize our nation’s security and I applaud his latest decision to uphold the rule of law our country was founded upon. Unilateral executive actions, such as DACA, offer the false hope of amnesty that led to a surge of illegal immigration and stole jobs from American citizens by giving illegal aliens work permits. This is why the House twice passed measures I introduced to freeze the DACA program. President Obama’s ‘pen and phone’ approach used illegal aliens as pawns in a political game, circumvented congressional authority, and cemented his legacy of lawlessness. I look forward to working with my colleagues in the coming months to fix our broken immigration system and establish laws that encourage immigrants and their families to come here legally.

Today, #bipartisan legislation I worked on as a member of House Committee on Energy and Commerce passed the House. The SELF DRIVE Act will allow for the safe deployment of self-driving technology, so that our roadways can be made safer. Self-driving vehicles mean fewer accidents and less traffic! Learn more at the link below >>

Today, with overwhelming bipartisan support, the House passed an emergency relief package for Hurricane Harvey recovery efforts. We stand with those in Texas and Louisiana who were affected by the devastation of this terrible storm.   The bill contains the full amount requested by the Administration – totaling $7.85 billion in emergency funding, including $7.4 billion for FEMA's Disaster Relief Fund (DRF). This will ensure FEMA can meet all current needs for response and recovery efforts, while also being prepared for any additional disasters that may arise. It also includes $450 million to support the Small Business Administration's disaster loan program to assist small businesses and homeowners begin to rebuild.

Raising the debt limit with no plan to curb government’s appetite for taxpayer funds is irresponsible. Out-of-control spending is a problem. We are offering solutions on behalf of the American taxpayer in a letter from the Republican Study Committee Steering Committee to Speaker Ryan. Let’s reduce – not increase – our debt.   You can read the letter at the link below.
NA

As we mark the 16th anniversary of the vilest terror attacks on American soil, we can’t help but remember where we were, what we were doing, and how we felt when we learned a plane struck the North Tower of the World Trade Center.  We were all watching the news, stunned, disbelieving what was happening at the twin towers, when Flight 77 whisked across the skyline of our Nation’s capital and crashed into the western façade of the Pentagon, causing death, destruction and a mass evacuation of government buildings, landmarks and public spaces. As we watched the events of that dark day unfold, we were awestruck, horrified, and left without words. For Tennesseans Bob Weaver and Mary Morgan Ketchel, however, it was all too real. As America was under attack, they were in the Capitol building amidst palpable fright, chaos, and confusion. Read their recollections of that day at the link below.  Where were you? What were you doing? Share your memories of that day in the comments.
As Irma continues with Tennessee in its path, please be safe, heed any warnings, and take necessary precautions. High winds are projected to be the main threat.
Our vision for tax reform → flatter, fairer, simpler #FlatterFairerSimpler

The Treasury Department released its Daily Treasury Statement showing the U.S. national debt jumped more than $317 billion to over $20 trillion after President Donald Trump signed legislation increasing the debt ceiling.   Our spending is out-of-control and we need to enact serious reforms to get our fiscal house in order. Americans are tired of all talk and no action. We cannot continue to kick the can down the road while hardworking families shoulder the financial burden of Washington’s reckless spending.
It was great to speak to the David Barton/WallBuilders Congressional Pastors’ Briefing this morning as they work to protect religious liberty. Honored to join you!

Americans want and need a flatter, fairer, simpler tax code that grows jobs and lets them keep more of their hard-earned paychecks. The President has laid out his vision for pro-growth tax reform. We are working to deliver #FlatterFairerSimpler. Click below to learn more:

Today the House asserted its Article I power of the purse and set appropriations levels for all 12 funding measures. This is a step toward cutting back the bureaucracy, restoring regular order to Congress, and putting Americans’ priorities into action. It is now on the Senate to come together on these bills so we can get them to the President’s desk.   While this package is a positive step forward, government spending is out-of-control and we need to enact serious reforms to get our fiscal house in order. Americans are tired of all talk and no action. That is why I introduced amendments to the appropriations bills that would require 1% across-the-board spending reductions for agencies like the EPA, IRS, Department of Labor, and Department of Education. Though they didn’t pass, I will continue working for responsible spending restraint.   Along with curbing our spending, we need serious, pro-growth tax reform so that Americans can keep more of their hard-earned paychecks and we can break the stagnant economic growth. Economic growth of 3% naturally brings with it more jobs and a higher standard of living. We are working to deliver a system that is fairer, flatter, and simpler for Americans at every income level. Click on the link below to read more about our fair and simple plan:

Today we recognize those who, in service to our country and defense of our freedoms, have been prisoners of war or are missing in action. We honor the selfless service of the brave men and women and the sacrifice of their families, loved ones, and their brothers and sisters in arms. Today a bold black and white flag will fly with our Stars and Stripes in their honor, and I urge everyone to take a moment today to honor those for whom the flag flies. We must never forget.

This Sunday marks the 230th anniversary of the signing of our Constitution. Each year, I spend time with students in classrooms all across our district to provide a lesson on the Constitution, how it came to be, what each Article does, and much more.    During each session I also fielded questions from the students. It was great to hear such well thought-out and formulated questions about our Constitution and my role and work in Congress. Some of the questions they posed included:   “Is the Constitution a living document?” “Why did the Founders write the Second Amendment?” "Should the 14th Amendment be expanded to include DACA?” “How do you help people as a Congressman?” “Is our government a democracy or a republic?” “What is your opinion on the race riots v. free speech?” “What are "inalienable rights" and where do they come from?” And much more…   It is a wonderful experience for me, and an educational and fun experience for the students.    On the video chat, I mentioned a number of helpful links on my website. Here they are!   Congressional Art Competition: https://blackburn.house.gov/constituentservices/artcompetition.htm   Military Service Academy Nominations: https://blackburn.house.gov/constituentservices/serviceacademynominations.htm   John S. Ziegler Student Leadership Conference at Austin Peay State University: http://www.apsu.edu/student-life/leadership/conference.php

Americans want and need a flatter, fairer, simpler tax code that grows jobs and lets them keep more of their hard-earned paychecks. Click the link to see what #FlatterFairerSimpler looks like: http://bit.ly/2haiCzt
Constitution Day continues across the 7th District as I live-video chat with students about the writing and importance of our nation's Constitution.

We had a wonderful day today in Giles County. Many of you may have heard me discuss tax relief, health insurance issues, rural broadband, getting the national debt under control, and the small business-friendly climate in Giles County with Don Eastep on WKSR this morning.   We also had great meetings at Martin Methodist College where I even held class with some of the students.  It was an honor to present replacement medals to Jim Culpepper, a Vietnam veteran who had his war medals stolen from his house last year. Following that, I met with members of the Giles County veterans Alliance where I listened to their concerns and took their questions on the issues they face and care about.   At the Tennessee College of Applied Technology in Pulaski, I had the privilege of helping present a check to the college from AT&T to support students in training for high-skill, technology-based jobs.   It was great to visit with officials from Elkton and Ardmore today as well. At the Ardmore Library  we delivered boxes of books that the Library of Congress donated. If you have an opportunity to visit the Ardmore Library, I highly suggest you stop by the Historical Room. It was incredible to see the treasure trove of vintage items and memorabilia.

It was an honor this week to reunite a Vietnam veteran with medals that had been stolen from his house last year. My office went to work when we heard of this story, and I was honored to be able to present Mr. Jim Culpepper of Pulaski with replacement medals. We are thankful for his service and that of all our brave men and women in uniform.

Another highlight of the week was spending time with John Minatra, a retired Army Master Sergeant who served in Vietnam. I presented Mr. Minatra with the Congressional Record in which I honored his service to our country. It was a great privilege, in the company of his family and fellow Army Rangers, to present it to him and recount his storied career. Leadership is not as it appears, but as it performs. We are all grateful for Mr. Minatra’s patriotism, dedication, and selfless service.
It's Fall Y'all!  I hope everyone had a good first day of the new season!
NA

Heartbroken by the shooting in Antioch today. We continue to pray for the friends and family of the victims of this horrific incident. Our thoughts are with the members of the Antioch community and we wish them strength in the aftermath of this tragedy.

The National Anthem is a source of American pride. Our flag is the ultimate symbol of unity - uniting all Americans under one banner as "Americans" - and we should respect it and those who have and continue to defend it.   Today I introduced a resolution in the House that reiterates current US code that during the playing of the National Anthem, "persons present who are not in uniform or are not members of the Armed Forces or veterans 'should face the flag and stand at attention with their right hand over their heart'"  Read the U.S. Code outlining this here: https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/36/301  Read my Resolution here: https://blackburn.house.gov/UploadedFiles/Anthem_resolution.pdf

This weekend we had the amazing opportunity to witness "Remembering WWII" in Linden, TN. This event honors the Greatest Generation, allowing WWII Veterans to share their stories and experience with Tennesseans.  The captivating WWII battle reenactment greeted us with the sounds of automatic gunfire, tanks and artillery shells, and the shouting of leaders directing their soldiers into the fight. Veterans, volunteers, and citizens of Linden put on a beautiful demonstration of our nation's history. As the troops advanced toward the enemy (in this case actors), three beautifully-restored WWII aircraft made strafing runs on targets over downtown Linden with cool smoke trails billowing across a perfectly crisp blue September sky. The cry of “MEDIC!” rang through the streets as actors fell to imaginary bullets. Men, women and children alike were dressed to the nines in 40s regalia, which truly brought history to life. I asked my mother what made this generation different, to which she replied, "We were all on the same team!"   I was honored to witness such a well-rehearsed event and look forward to attending again.

Everyone agrees we need tax relief for families and for businesses, both small and large. How do we do it?  #FlatterFairerSimpler is the fastest route. I spoke with Fox News' Shannon Bream on America's Newsroom about our efforts. Find out more here: http://bit.ly/2haiCzt

Tax relief is on the way in our #FlatterFairerSimpler Tax Reform Framework. The goals are straight forward: more jobs, fairer taxes, bigger paychecks for hardworking Americans. Click on the link to learn more.  http://bit.ly/2haiCzt

The SOFTWARE Act is implemented. I authored it to speed the delivery of health care technology to doctors and patients. mHealth apps and informatics put YOU in charge of your health and wellness.  These innovators now have the opportunity to bring consumer-based health care to the marketplace with record speed.
So glad to have my colleague Congressman Steve Scalise back at work! Welcome back!

Help is on the way. The House just passed the Disaster Tax Relief and Airport and Airway Extension Act. Hurricane Maria left a wake of destruction in U.S. territories, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands—beyond anything I could imagine. This is only the beginning of the relief efforts, but families and communities impacted by Hurricanes Maria, Harvey and Irma can now begin to rebuild their lives with resources freed up by this bill.   As FEMA continues to respond with relief supplies for the 3.5 million Americans impacted in our territories, I’m grateful President Trump has committed to increase the level of federal funding, waive the Jones Act, and will be traveling to Puerto Rico to observe relief efforts.

“…that baby feels a pain, that baby responds.”  Science has proven that, at 20 weeks, unborn children are capable of feeling pain. Yet thousands of these babies are killed each year in violent late-term abortions. I spoke on the House floor in support of H.R. 36, the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act of 2017 to protect these unborn children from this horrific procedure. Watch my remarks below:

The availability of health care for children in Tennessee is a priority for me, which is why I supported a bill in the House Committee on Energy and Commerce to reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP). CHIP covers around 72,000 children in Tennessee and works to ensure no child falls between the cracks of the Medicaid system.    We also marked up a bill to reauthorize funding for community health centers, which provide valuable service in our state. During the mark-up, Democrat members offered an amendment to strip language preventing your hard-earned dollars from paying for elective abortion. I spoke against that amendment and am glad to share that it failed. You can watch my remarks in the video below.  You can get more information on all 9 bills we marked up here: http://bit.ly/2fMFIbu

Thank you President Donald J. Trump. Since 2008 I’ve worked to pass my Across State Lines Health Insurance bill. Now it is a reality. For the millions with one or no choice in health care and for those who have been priced out of the marketplace due to skyrocketing premiums and outrageous deductibles, this is great news.

The Cost-Sharing Reduction payments were unauthorized, illegal, and amounted to little more than a giveaway to insurance companies. Congress alone has the power to authorize and appropriate funds for government programs, not the executive branch. President Donald J. Trump's decision to end these payments affirms the ruling in House v. Burwell and reaffirms the Constitutional separation of powers in charging Congress to address this issue.

Yesterday Hankook USA opened its first U.S. manufacturing plant in Clarksville, Tennessee. This plant is a major boon for the Clarksville area, creating 1,000 jobs and slated to bring another 800 in phase 2 of its operations. I was honored to take part in the ceremony and thank the company’s leadership for bringing their first U.S. plant to Montgomery County!

What an honor to join with leaders from Franklin, Tennessee and   Middle Tennessee yesterday morning, celebrating the groundbreaking of Harpeth Square—a milestone development for downtown Franklin with hotel, housing and retail space. Excellence doesn’t happen by accident, and this is a testament to the hard work and efforts of a great group of community leaders and neighbors. Congratulations!

The vicious opioid crisis gripping our country touches people from all walks of life. The issue goes beyond just stopping the flow of opioids to pill mills or shady internet pharmacies that pencil-whip prescriptions without so much as a phone call between doctor and patient. There are also millions of legitimate patients who rely on medication to control pain and treat chronic illnesses. Congress has been working on this issue for years, but more must be done – and now.   Read my op-ed on the issue at the link below:

The opioid crisis gripping our country touches people from all walks of life. We all know someone who is affected by it and too many families are being left to grieve the passing of a loved one. Congress has been working on this issue for years, but more must be done – and now.  Today, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce will hold a full committee hearing to continue examining the epidemic. My colleagues and I are determined to continue fighting with every resource at our disposal to protect communities and develop a comprehensive strategy to end opioid addiction.  Get more information on the hearing and watch live at the link below.

Honored to receive the Guardian of Senior’s Rights award from the 60 Plus Association this morning. Thank you to my good friend and legendary entertainer Pat Boone for his kind words. I am proud to be a “dependable, fine friend of seniors.”

Honored to be invited by the President to attend today’s event declaring the opioid epidemic a public health emergency. Tennesseans are no stranger to the destruction this epidemic wreaks – we cannot afford to sit idly by as it continues. It is critical that we use every weapon available to us to fight this devastating epidemic. The President’s decision to declare this a public health emergency gives states and communities more tools to address the crisis and unleashes government resources to better help those in need of help. There is more to do, but today’s announcement is an important step toward bringing this scourge to an end.

Many of you have contacted the office about the news stories about the Uranium One deal and the Clinton Foundation. As part of our oversight work here in the house, my office has been looking into the Clinton foundation and the appearance of “pay to play” activities and improprieties while Hillary Clinton was Secretary of State. In 2016, we authored a report outlining our findings, our efforts to have other agencies investigate, and the responses we received from those agencies. With the latest news bringing up more accusations and questions, House committees have opened further investigations into the matter. I support their efforts and will do what I can to get the facts.   You can read the report here: http://bit.ly/2hezKl3
Bravo Clay Walker! Great job with the National Anthem tonight at World Series game 5. Cutest ever with son William by his side!
Convening House Committee on Energy and Commerce Communications and Technology Subcommittee hearing on State Perspectives on FirstNet. Click the link below to watch!

It has been 31 years since our tax code has been reformed, and in that time it has only grown full of special interest carve-outs and loopholes. Taxes shouldn’t be complicated, and our tax code shouldn’t be over 70,000 pages long.   Hardworking taxpayers want and need relief from a bloated tax code, and today we introduced a relief package that aims to increase jobs, grow the economy, and allow Americans to keep more of their own paychecks. But our work is not done. As we work through the details of the plan, we must continue to champion our conservative principles and make good on our promise to deliver a flatter, fairer, and simpler tax code.   More info on the bill, including a summary, can be found at the link below.

Today my fellow Members of Congress and I sent a letter to Attorney General Sessions requesting an update on criminal referrals made during the Select Panel’s investigation into Planned Parenthood’s gruesome practice of selling baby body parts for profit. As the letter states, “we must pursue this potential criminal activity with all available resources. Failing to do so erodes the dignity of the lives of unborn children, endangers the health of women, and emboldens a subculture of moral depravity.”  Read the full letter here.

Each year, on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month, Americans commemorate the end of major hostilities in WWI by celebrating our military heroes on Veterans Day. Please join me in thanking active service members and veterans for volunteering to defend our great Nation. They are just one percent of our population, but their worldwide influence is tremendous.  To all who served, THANK YOU!

Yesterday I introduced the Clear Law Enforcement for Criminal Alien Removal, or CLEAR Act, legislation I have authored and pushed since 2007, to ensure that state and local law enforcement officials have the tools necessary to require that the federal government deport criminal illegal aliens from the United States. We must stand strong in our fight to secure the border and strengthen our interior enforcement in order to keep our cities and towns safe. Sanctuary city policies promote open borders and encourage more illegal immigration. This bill would be a solid step toward greater security for Americans across the country.   Read my op-ed below on the bill and why we need to pass it.
Such a wonderful and influential poem by Howard Schnauber. It’s important to thank a veteran each and every day, and not just on Veterans Day!

The devastating impact of the 2017 hurricane season is still taking a toll on our nation, and reminds us about the importance of coordination between federal, state, and local governments in response efforts.   This is why I’ve introduced the Good Samaritan Health Professionals Act, which would limit the liability of health care professionals who volunteer to provide health care services in response to a disaster.   Watch my opening statement at the Subcommittee on Environment Hearing on “Response and Recovery to Environmental Concerns from the 2017 Hurricane Season” here!   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6PcGbBweLi8

Pay to play? I led a letter to the FBI in July 2016 with over 60 of my colleagues calling for an investigation of the Clinton Foundation's involvement with the Uranium One deal.   The American people deserve answers. Read the letter here:
Want the real scoop on what Tennesseans in the 7th Congressional District need to know about the House #taxbill?   Watch here to find out!
Big day on Capitol Hill! Watch here to find out what I'm up to today!

Too many families can't afford health insurance under the Affordable Care Act.   That is why repealing Obamacare's individual mandate--which you're going to see in the Senate tax bill--is so important.

Don’t be fooled by the name “net-neutrality.”   Net-neutrality regulates the internet, and is the opposite of a free and open marketplace. I fully support FCC Chairman Ajit Pai's decision. There's a lot of confusion about tomorrow's FCC vote to restore internet freedom. Watch this interview to find out why I fully support Ajit Pai- we need a free and open internet.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2017-12-13/rep-blackburn-net-neutrality-vote-a-positive-step-video
We're for a free and open internet. It's time for Congress to do its job.
Here's a weekly roundup of what I did in D.C.

Could you get online before Obama’s net neutrality regulations? The internet was not broken, and did not need the federal government to place overbearing regulations to “fix” it. These regulations hurt broadband expansion (which is the ability to get a provider), and network investment (which helps companies innovate so you can have faster internet). We need to permanently enact rules that prevent blocking and throttling-but that’s Congress’ job, not the FCC.   Tune into my interview tonight with @wkrn

The internet needs light-touch regulation so you are guaranteed fair and free access. Obama-era net neutrality rules hurt investment and innovation. We need our internet across the country to be up to 21st century standards.    https://www.wsj.com/article_email/the-internet-is-free-again-1513297405-lMyQjAxMTI3MzEwNTUxNjU0Wj/

It's taken 31 years, but the time is finally here. I'm on my way to vote yes for #taxreform. This bill will give much needed tax relief to hardworking families, and allow small businesses to once again thrive. The government isn't entitled to your hard-earned dollars.

No blocking. No throttling. The Open Internet Preservation Act will ensure the internet is a free and open space. This legislation is simple, it provides light-touch regulation so companies can invest and innovate, and make sure our internet is up to 21st century standards.

Ready to join Fox News show to discuss why we need to pass tax reform. It's time for us to get back to our core American values- less taxes, more personal freedom. The government is not entitled to your paycheck.

My office is proud to host the Military Service Academy Day on Saturday, August 26. High school students interested in applying to a military service academy are invited to join representatives from the U.S. Air Force, Coast Guard, Merchant Marine, Military, and Naval Academies, and Army and Air Force R.O.T.C. for an informative day concerning your future in college and with the military. This is a great opportunity for students and parents in Tennessee's 7th district to learn more about the admission process and receiving a congressional nomination.   Our Service Academy Day will be held at Franklin High School from 10 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. We hope you will be a part of this special day!  For more information call (615) 591-5161 or email Jackie.Collins@mail.house.gov  Please park in the REAR parking lot behind Franklin High School. Enter through the doors between the large columns in the back of the building.
